In a linear program, decision variables are not limited to integer values. In fact, they are divisible. In certain situations, the divisibility assumption does not hold as some decision variables can only be an integer. Methods of integer programming, which are not in the scope of this book, overcome this obstacle. The last assumption is certainty, which means that each parameter of a linear programming model is constant in all conditions.
